div.p: Dr. Mather's ESSAY on Mans not knowing his Time
A brief ESSAY ON Mans not knowing his TIME: THE Juſt INFERENCES from it, AND THE Great ADVANTAGES of it. Upon a Special and Mournful Occaſion.

p.hi: So teach us to Number our Days.

l.hi: Fieres ſi ſcires unum tua tempora Menſem;
Rides, quum non ſint forſitan una Dies?

div.p: In Engliſh.
div.l: T'would make thee ſerious, didſt thou ſurely know,
Down to the Grave thou in a Month muſt go:
Why to vain Mirth a looſe then canſt thou give,
Not knowing that thou haſt a Day to live?
div.p: BOSTON in NE Printed by B. Green, for Samuel Gerriſh, the lower End of Corn-hill, 1727.

div.head: INSTRUCTION Fetch'd from IGNORANCE.
On the Sudden DEATH of a Young Gentleman. Jan. 14.1726, 7.
div.p: AND therefore there is no Man in the Auditory at this Time, who knows any other but that This may be the Laſt Time of his being here; For ought that any One knows, This may be the Laſt Sabbath he ſhall have ſhining on him; This the Laſt Sermon he ſhall have ſpeaking to him. Certainly This alone may be enough to beſpeak from us, a Great Attention to what we have now before us.
Man knoweth not is Time.] The Text is capable to have a Lively, yea, a Daily Paraphraſe made upon it.—What think you of ſuch a Paraphraſe as This? —

—A Young Gentleman,Mr. SAMUEL HIRST. Deſcended of worthy Progenitors; Accompliſhed with the Advantages of a Liberal as well as Religious Education; Recommended unto the Loves & Hopes of his Friends by many Deſireable circumſtances; After very little more than Three Times Seven Years of Appearance in the World; Be to all Apprehenſion in perfect Health; in the midſt of Buſineſs, and of Company;— And — But here the Story Stops! — At once to fall down Dead in the Street! — The Mounting & Glowing Spark, in a Moment go out, and fall down into the common Heap of Aſhes! — This is a Paraphraſe, which the Great GOD has juſt now given us, on, Man knows not his Time. An affecting Paraphraſe! Go to now, ye that ſay, To Morrow we will do this or that! ye know not what ſhall be on the Morrow. What is your Life? It is even a vapour that appears for a little time, and then vaniſhes away.
BUT the matter muſt be further look'd into.

MY Text is found in a Book Entituled, The Preacher. It ſeems, the Things which are in this Book inſiſted on, are ſuch as it well becomes a Preacher to inſiſt upon. We have here the Retractations of a Solomon, writing a Treatiſe upon, The Chief End of Man; An Aged Solomon, after much Experience, confeſſing his own Errors, and correcting of ours, upon that Important Subject. The Word which we render, The Preacher, carries in it ſome Intimations of, A Soul upon Recollection. We have here that Enquiry managed, What is
true Happineſs? And, How, or Where, is true Happineſs is to be met withal! Upon a Serious Recollection, it is here pronounced, That our Temporal Happineſs is to Enjoy Chearfully what we Poſſeſs Honeſtly. But, Wo to that Man, who Stops here; who is put off ſo; who knows none but a Temporal Happineſs. There is an Eternal Happineſs, which a Man ought always and chiefly to be concern'd about : An Happineſs to be found in the Day when G O D ſhall bring every work into Judgment. And the way to obtain this Happineſs is for a Man to Fear G O D and keep His Commandments. In the proſecution of theſe things, very pertinent are the Remarks made in this Book, upon the Diverſe Vanities, whereof Men do in this Life undergo the grievous Vexations. One of thoſe Diverſe Vanities, is Remark'd in the Text before us; Man knoweth not his Time. It refers to ſuch occurrences, as the preceeding Verſe takes notice of. Time intends the Changes which befalls us in Time; The Changes which are alſo called Chances, becauſe we ſee not the Cauſes of them. The Reaſons as well as the Seaſons are ſecret unto us. But above all, Time intends the end of our Time. It is our Death which is our Time : The Time wherein we are to Dy, and we are to have no more Time allow'd unto us. The uncertainty of this Time, wherein it pleaſes the Holy Lord of Time, who Inhabits Eternity to keep us, has here ſome elegant Illuſtrations and Reſemblances. The Fiſh Knows not the Time of its being taken in the Nett. The Bird knows not
the Time of its being taken in the Snare; So are Men Suddenly taken by the Evil-Time of a Dying Hour. The Netts of Death are ſpread for us. The Snares of Death are laid for us. Man knows not the Time of his being taken in them.
ATTEND unto a DOCTRINE of an Importance as Uſeful as Awful, to be at all Times thought upon.

p.hi: LITTLE do People know the Times that are hereafter to paſs over them : Little do we know what Changes are to come, and when they are to come upon us.

div.p: CONTINGENCIES are Things which we cannot have a certain knowledge of. Tis at beſt, but an Opinion, tis at beſt but a Conjecture, that we can have of them. Now, with reſpect unto us, what are all Futurities, but Contingencies.

MY DOCTRINE is a String which the Quill of Solomon did very much harp upon. And moſt certainly the Wiſdom of a Solomon could not be expreſs'd without Strong Impreſſions from ſuch a Meditation. Tis bewailed by Solomon as the Miſery of Man, Eccl. VIII. 7. He knoweth not that which ſhall be; For who can tell him when it ſhall be! Oh! may we have the Wiſdom to make our Advantage of this Miſery; ſince we do know what we have to do, that we may be prepared for that which ſhall be.
THIS, This is the Tendency of the Meditation upon which we are now proceeding.
WE will Inquire, Firſt, What is there in the Times paſſing over us, which we muſt not have the Fore-knowledge of?
TWO words will fully eno' expreſs the matter.

Firſt LITTLE do we Fore-know the Quantity of our Time; or what will be the Duration of it. Man knoweth not his Time; in that he knows not, whether it will be a Longer Time, or a Shorter Time. As it has been ſaid, What man is he that liveth, and ſhall not ſee Death? So it may be ſaid, What man alive is there, who knows when he ſhall ſee Death? We are told, The living know that they ſhall Dy. But which of the Living are they who know when they are to Dye? The Preſages that ſome few have had of their Time, are extraordinary! One ſaid, Gen XXVII. 2. I am old, I know not the Day of my Death. And the Young does as little know the Day of his Death. It is an ancient ſaying, If an old Man has Death ſtanding before his Face, a young Man has Death ſtanding behind his Back. The Time of its giving the Fatal ſtroke, is as little known to the one, as to the other. One that is in his full ſtrength, being wholly at eaſe and quiet, and having his Bones moiſtned with morrow; Even ſuch an one does not know his Time; for even ſuch an one may Dy at this very Time. One that is in Bitterneſs of Soul, and never Eats with pleaſure, becauſe of the Infirmities under what he languiſhes; even ſuch an one alſo does not know his Time. For even ſuch an one may be Repriev'd from Death beyond expectation; and ſee many Stronger ones ly down in the Duſt before him. We do all know, That it
is appointed unto man once to dy. But which of us does know his appointed Time for it; or when he is to Dy? Ordinarily, of that Day & Hour knoweth no Man.

Secondly, LITTLE do we Foreknow the Quality of our Time; or what we are to Encounter in it. Shall we have a Good Time, or a Bad Time of it? Man knoweth not! In our Time ſhall we ſee Days of Pleaſure, or Days of Sorrow? Man knoweth not! Shall we have our Time ſweetned with much Proſperity, or embittered with much Adverſity? Man knoweth not! The World may not prove either ſo Good as we hope, or ſo Bad as we fear? 'Tis moſt commonly ſo. Some look for a ſadder Time than ever does arrive unto them. So did the Iſraelitiſh Hero, when he ſaid, I ſhall one day periſh by the hand of Saul. But much oftner do Men look for a better Time, than what anon comes unto them. They ſay, I ſhall never be moved; But, GOD hides His Face, and they are Troubled. When Joſeph was a Priſoner and his Foot they did humble with the affliction of a chain; The Iron, that did penetrate into his very Soul: Did he know what was to be done for him, when the King constituted him to be the Ruler of his Houſe; yea, and the Governour of all that was poſſeſs'd by him. When Haman was in all the Grandeur of the Perſion Court, and the chief Miniſter of State there; Did he know how near he and his Family were, to a matchleſs confuſion? What Accidents we are to meet withal, whether Joyful Accidents, or Woful Accidents, we muſt not know, indeed ſo much as one day before hand.
So we are admoniſhed; Prov. XXVII. 1. Thou knoweſt not what a Day may bring forth. O Man, Thou knoweſt not, what may This Day befall thee in thy Perſon, in thy Family, in thy Intereſt. Thou knowest not what may be the Tidings that will This Day be brought unto thee. Thou knoweſt not in the Evening what may befall thee before the Morning, or in the Morning what ſhall befall thee before the Evening; Any more than the Men upon whom the Tower of Siloam fell, that the Tower was to fall, while they were under it.

THE Articles wherein you have had ſet before you, the Future Events of our Times, whereof our GOD will keep us in the greateſt Uncertainties, are then theſe Two; Firſt, That which is the greateſt of all our Changes; And, then, all the Changes which may before That come upon us. Our Meditation muſt not eaſily, and preſently diſmiſs theſe Articles of our Times which are unknown unto us. But before we paſs any further, Let an earneſt EXHORTATION prevail with us, To Entertain this Meditation, and he duely affected with it. Oh! may this Thought be often rolling in our Minds; I know not my Time, nor do I know any thing that is to befal me in my Time! And may our Minds feel the power of it; bring our Lives under the power of it! The very Pagans would ſometimes give an Entertainment unto this Meditation; and ſay, Neſcis quid ſerus Veſper vebat; O Man, Thou knoweſt not what may before Night be to come upon thee. Certainly, It becomes Chriſtians to give a more
affecting entertainment unto ſuch a Meditation.

Firſt; THE caſe of Mortality is above all to be thus conſidered; That Man knows not his Time, when his Mortality muſt have the Operation of it finiſhed. Man lies under a Sentence of Death; and the Time for Execution is determined with GOD; Lord, The number of our Months is with thee; Thou haſt appointed our Bounds, that we cannot paſs. But Man muſt not know the Time, until the Executioner come and bring the Bow-ſtring. There is no Day that breaks upon any Man, but for ought he knows, His Time is come, and the Day of his Death. Sudden Deaths are ſome of thoſe Things, whereto all Men living are expoſed. We find it ſuppoſed, Numb VI. 9. A man may die very ſuddenly. 'Tis what we ſee fulfill'd on great Numbers; We need not for the proof of it quote the Book of Numbers. The commiſſions which our glotious GOD gives to the Angel of Death are often kept ſecret until the very Day, that he comes and ſwears unto them, No more Time ſhall be given them. It may be the Portion of Wicked Men to Dy ſuddenly. The profane Men, who can ſay of the Thing they never once thought upon, They thought no more of it than of their Dying Day; find it according to their word; Their Dying Day comes at a Time which they thought not of. The Men of Sodom; Did they know their Time? A bright fair, Sunſhiny Morning, found them wallowing in all Impurities; Before Night the Vengeance of Eternal Fire came down upon them. The Egyptians; Did they know their Time? In the Morning
they were full of brave Expectations to divide Spoils and Slaves among them, and to do wondrous Exploits. That Night they were Drown'd, and Damn'd; the Sea covered them. The Philistines; Did they know their Time? In the Morning they had nothing in their Eye, but the Sports of an Holiday. E're the Night came, they were cruſh'd all to pieces. Ananias & Sapphira; Did they know their Time. They came out well to the Meeting, and they are carried home Dead! It may be the Portion of Godly Men alſo to Dy ſuddenly. It may be a Privilege granted by GOD unto ſome of His moſt Favoured ones, to Dy ſuch a Death. Uzzah, Did he know his Time; In the Morning of the Day, when the Ark was to be carried into the City of David? or, The Prophet ſent unto Jeroboam; Did he know his Time, in the Morning of the Day when the Lion fell upon him? Others leſs obnoxious find it ſo.

Yea, Secondly; THE Caſe of every Calamity is thus to be conſidered. Man knows not his Time, when that Calamity will befal him, wherein GOD will perform the Thing that is appointed for him. One that has an Husband, or a Father, in the Morning, does not know, but before Night, the ſtate of a Widow, or an Orphan may be Theirs: The Sun may ſet at Noon with us, and leave us in a Sudden Darkneſs. A Job has his Houſe full of Children in the Morning; but he does not know that before Night, he ſhall have neither Houſe nor Children left unto him. In this evil World, every Man knows, that his Dependence may be like that of the Apoſtles, Afflictions wait for me: But
then he muſt add like the Apoſtle. Act. XX. 22. Not knowing the Things that ſhall befal me. And much more, Not knowing the Time when they ſhall befal me.

IT was counted a Flight of Wiſdom; All that I know, is that I know nothing! It will be wiſely done of us to make the knowledge of our Ignorance in this point, as efficacious as may be upon us; This I know, that man knoweth not his Time.
WE will enquire, Secondly; Whence is it, that we muſt not have the Fore-knowledge of the Times that are to paſs over us?

Now, Firſt; THERE is for it, the Firſt Reaſon of all things; the grand Reaſon of all Reaſons. The Sovereign will of GOD; That is Reaſon enough. The Sovereignty of the Great GOD will be maintained in it. It was a juſt Acknowledgment; Pſal. XXXI. 15. O Lord, my Times are in thy Hand. It was a juſt Admonition; Act. I. 7. It is not for you to know the Times, which the Father has put in His own power. All that ſhall befall us in our Times, is Decreed by the GOD that made us. Now, the Decree is by our Sovereign kept a Secret: For ſuch is His will and pleaſure, that it ſhould be ſo. There is a Glorious One, who is in our Tranſlation of the Bible, called, The Ancient of Days. The Original is, The Appointer of Times. 'Tis fit, that our Times remain unknown to any but Him that has the Appointing of the Times.
BUT, there is more than this to be ſaid of the matter.
Firſt, IT is from the Pitty and Mercy of our Gracious GOD unto the poor Children of Men, that they muſt not know their Time, nor what is to befall them in their Time.

IT may well be aſcribed unto the Pitty of our GOD, That we do not know our Time; For ſuch a knowledge would very much deſtroy the comfort of our Time; very much make for us a moſt uncomfortable Time, Here, Here, moſt emphatically; He that increaſeth Knowledge increaſeth Sorrow. It would mightily take away the comfort which we take in any thing under the Sun, if we knew aforehand, When and How we are to take our leave of that comfort. It is reported concerning Eliſha, 2 King. VIII. 11, 12. The man of God wept; And Hazael ſaid, Why weepeth my Lord? And he anſwered, Becauſe I know the evil, that thou wilt do. Thus, If a Man know the evil Time that is to befall himſelf, or his Houſe, and the Time of the Evil, he would fall a weeping at it; into ſuch a weeping, that he would be able to find little Reliſh in the gifts of GOD unto him. The Anticipations of Trouble would break the Hearts of Men, if they knew before hand all the Trouble that is to come upon them, and the Time when it will come. Our Lord has told us; Math. VI. 34. Sufficient unto the Day is the evil thereof. It will be ſoon enough to know the evil, when the Day comes. If we ſhould know the evil before the Day, it would multiply exceedingly, & keep growing & growing, and ſcalding upon us; we ſhould be more ſcalded before it falls, than we ſhould be in the Actual Falling of it. It is a moſt
conſpicuous Difference between a Man, & a Bruit. And I look upon it, as no deſpicable Argument, that Man is made for a World that is to come. A Man has a ſtrong Apprehenſion of what is to come : And what he knows is to come, he feels it Exquiſitely, he feels it Wonderfully. Oh! Should many a Man know, At ſuch a Time, ſhall my Houſe be laid in Aſhes; Or, At ſuch a Time, a Relative that is the Deſire of my Eyes will be taken from me: Or, at ſuch a Time I ſhall my ſelf be carried unto my long Home, and the Mourners for me ſhall walk about the Streets; Verily, this knowledge would cauſe an unſpeakable Anguiſh in him. Such a knowledge of our Time, would cauſe a cry to be heard among us, like that which was once heard in Aegypt; A cry whereof they kept an Anniverſary commemoration among them, for many Ages.

Again; IT may be aſcribed unto the Mercy of GOD, that we do not know our Time. For, hereby we come the better to Know and to Do, the Duty of our Time. Here is indeed an Ignorance, that is very truly, and very juſtly, the Mother of Devotion. Our not knowing our Time, and the Things to come, does train us up, to a Filial Faith in the Fatherly Care, of the Lord, who only has all thoſe Things in His own Hands. We read; Jam. IV. 14, 15. Ye know not what ſhall be on the Morrow;—Ye ought to ſay, If the Lord will, we ſhall live, and do this or that. We Refer our ſelves to the Will of GOD, with the more of Reſignation; a moſt humble and lovely Reſignation; becauſe we know not what ſhall be on
the Morrow. And our Preparation, a Watchful and Prayerful Preparation for the worſt that may happen to us; This is promoted by our not knowing our Time, and what ſhall happen to us. It is preſſed upon us; Mar. XIII. 33. Take heed, watch, and pray; for ye know not when the Time is. Becauſe we know not the Time, when we or ours are to Dy, or what is to befall us; If this won't put us upon Watching and Praying, and keep us in a way of Holy walking, I don't know what will! I know not my Time, nor what I am to ſee in a very Little Time. A Man of any ſenſe will think ſo. But Methinks, One that has the leaſt grain of ſenſe, muſt go on to think; I deſire now to keep alive the conſtant Fear of GOD, all the Time that He ſhall allow me; I deſire to be armed with Patience and Submiſſion, for all the uneaſy Things which in my Remaining Time I may find reſerved for me. Sirs, we muſt yield a Blindfold Obedience unto GOD; This Blindfold Obedience is a Well aim'd Obedience.

Secondly. THERE is a Dreadful Judgment of GOD, upon Wicked Men in it, that they muſt not know their Time. The wrath of GOD upon Wicked Men muſt overtake them. After what manner muſt it overtake them? We read; Pſal. XI. 6. Upon the wicked He ſhall rain ſnares— and an horrible tempeſt, We read; Pſal. LXXIII. 18, 19. Surely, Thou haſt ſet them in ſlippery places; — How are they brought into Deſolation, as in a Moment? Of the Wicked Man, we are told; Pſal. XXXVII. 13. The Lord ſhall laugh at him, for He ſees that his Day is coming. Why;
The Man does not ſee it himſelf! This gives a greater Triumph to the Juſtice of GOD, in the Day that comes upon him. The Vengeance of GOD upon a wicked Man, muſt come Irreſiſtibly. It comes at once, and that makes it the more Irreſiſtible. A Whirlwind of Wrath muſt come upon a wicked Man. A Whirlwind, that muſt riſe at once. It muſt gather Suddenly, It muſt be big with terrible Thunder. It muſt break him to pieces, before he has any Time to look about him. He muſt not know his Time. No; He muſt be Surprized by the Vengeance of GOD.
BUT now, Let us make our more particular Improvement of theſe Faithful ſayings.

I. SINCE our GOD will not let us know our Time, we muſt beware of curious Inquiries after the Future Events of our Time. There is a certain Prerogative, of which Vain Man that would be wiſe, is very ambitious; That is, that Prerogative of Divination: Men would fain know their Time, and what is to come hereafter. And, how many curſed Arts of Divination have been invented for the gratification of this Curioſity! But, O vain Man, Thou lifteſt up thy hand unto a Forbidden Tree of Knowledge, when thou art Inquiſitive about Futurities. Take the Rebuke of GOD; Deut. XXIX. 29. Secret Things belong unto the Lord our GOD. Indeed there are ſome Things to come, whereof we may commendably & profitably be Inquiſitive; But they are ſuch Things as our GOD has Reveled
unto us, in the Prophecies of our Bible. Theſe are Things, which Piety would make us Deſire to look into. The Tribe which has Underſtanding in the Times, is to be applauded for it. They who Deſcern not the Signs of the Times, to be upbraided for it. But what is this, to the Impious and Criminal Curioſity of them, who will needs be prying into Faturities, which GOD will have to be concealed from us? I tell you, The Bethſhemites might as well pry into the Ark of GOD. For Men to graſp after ſuch a Knowledge of their Time, as may indiſpoſe them for a modeſt waiting upon the Providence of GOD; Verily, 'Tis a great Iniquity. Hence, to conſult Aſtrologers and Fortune-tellers, about our Time, and the Events thereof; 'Tis a Crime; As to Believe them, 'tis a Weakneſs, 'tis a Madneſs. Thoſe Prophetaſters; Pittiful Jugglers Mankind ſtrangely degrade and diſgrace themſelves, by ſuffering thoſe Jugglers to impoſe upon them. Indeed, they have no Rules worth a ſtraw to go by. If they do any thing to purpoſe, 'tis by a Satanical Impulſe. Their pretended Rules of Art are meer cheats. And the wretches themſelves uſually have ſuch Tragical, but Unforeſeen Things befalling of them, 'tis marvellous that the credit of the whole Sect is not for ever Extinguiſhed. Indeed, one can't but wonder, as the Roman Orator long ago did about their Augurs, how the wretches can look one another in the Face, without a ſcornful ſneer at the cheats which they agree to put upon the Vast Herd that pay Regard unto them. Chriſtians, Indulge not the Vice of
a Mind Curious to know your Time. 'Tis a crime, that will ripen People for the puniſhments which uſe to come upon Sinners, when they have quite fill'd up the meaſure of their Iniquity. We have ſeen fearful Examples of Perſons, that have gone to Forbidden-ways of coming at the knowledge of their Time, and they have never ſeen one Good Day after it. When Soul was gone ſo far, as to conſult a Witch, Then the wrath of GOD would bear no longer with him!

II WE muſt not know our Time; Then 'tis a Folly for us, to preſume upon a Time, which our GOD has given us no Aſſurance of. Such is the Folly of them, who preſume upon an Happy Time, while they make it a Time of Impiety, a Time of Impenitence, a Day of Provocation. O preſumpteous ones, In all the word of GOD, where have you a promiſe of an Happy Time, for ungodly People, going on ſtill in their Treſpaſſes? Yea, ſuch is the Folly of all, who preſume that their Time will always be juſt what it is. For Men to Dream that all things will continue Long unaltered from what they are at this Time: Let me tell you, This. Dream is uſually a very deadly Symptom. When Men are moſt Secure, and are Fearleſs of any Alteration upon their Circumſtances; Then 'tis, that the Deadlieſt Alterations are moſt near unto them. An Old Man brags, he is as Well and Strong as he has been theſe Many Years; he hopes he ſhall yet ſee Many Years. He Dies this Year! Oh! Don't fall into a Dead Sleep of Security. 'Tis a tremendous
paſſage; [And mark what I tell you, There are whole Nations that will VERY QUICKLY have it fulfill'd upon them!] 1 Theſ. V. 3. When they ſay, peace and ſafety, then ſudden deſtruction cometh. When and How is a Belſhazzar taken off? Inſtead of a Fooliſh Security be evermore Suſpicious, and ſtill Suſpect what may happen between the Cup and the Lip, and with an eaſy Frame of Mind Leave all in the Hand of a Glorious GOD ready to take any Cup that He ſhall order for you. Say with an eaſy Mind; I know not my Time; and I am content that I do not know it. But, O my God, I know in my Time nothing will befall me, but what thou ordereſt, and I chearfully refer all to thy ordering! But I will go on, and charge this Folly upon all that preſume on the Time to come. While Man knoweth not his Time, thou mayſt O Man know ſo much of thy Time, That the Preſent Time is thy only Time. All Thy Time, is This Time. Do not Rely upon a To-Morrow, or upon, A more convenient Seaſon, for any thing that thou art now to do for the Good of Thy ſelf or Others O Do with thy might, what thy Hand find to do. For know this; Thou knoweſt of no other Time for the doing of it.
III. WHAT now remains, but this Word of Command, Make all Ready! Oh! Let us make Ready for whatever Times are to paſs over us.

MAKE Ready for Changes of Every Sort. This do by getting into that poſture of Mind, which is deſcribed ſo, Pſal. CXII. 7. He ſhall
not be afraid of evil tidings; His Heart is fixed, truſting in the Lord.

BUT above all, Make Ready for that Greateſt and Sureft of all our Changes; The DEATH of which I may ſay, The Day is Near, it is near, and it haſtneth greatly! Indeed, for the animation of all PIETY, this Meditation, Man knows not his Time; Tis an Inſtrument of which I may ſay, There is none like it. How would it come like a Red-hot Stone from the Altar, to enflame our Devotions, if when we are going to Prayer, we ſhould think, I know not my Time: This may be the laſt Time that ever I ſhall call upon GOD, before I am fetch'd away to appear before Him! What Salt would it ſeaſon our Speech withal, if in our Converſation with our Friends we ſhould think, I know not my Time: This may be the laſt Time of my Converſing with ſuch as I am now talking to! At what a rate ſhould we Sabbatize, if upon the Arrival of the Lords-Day, we ſhould think, I know not my Time: This may be the laſt Lords Day that I ſhall ſee before my Dying Day! But the Grand concern of PIETY, is in that, Be Ye Ready. And, My Friends, That you may be Ready for the Death, whereof you do not know the Time, you do know, That you muſt begin Immediately to Live unto GOD. Your Immediate CONVERSION to GOD, This you do know, is abſolutely Neceſſary; And your coming into His Covenant, by conſenting that your Great SAVIOUR ſhould fulfill for you and in you the Good pleaſure of His Goodneſs. By this you make ſure of Grace, and of Glory, and
of Every Good Thing: and you lay hold on Eternal Life. This you do know, That without this, you have the Wrath of GOD abiding on you; If you Dy without this, you Dy in your Sins; and you paſs into a World which cannot be without a Shuddering Horror tho't upon! People refuſe to Turn to GOD, and Cloſe with CHRIST, and Fly from SIN. They do it by Procrastinating; By putting off to Another Time. O the Phrenſy of this Procraſtination! Unadviſed People, You know not your time. And therefore This you know; This Work muſt not be left undone untill Another Time. If your Time ſhould be done, before that Work be done, which muſt be done that you may be Reconciled unto GOD, O Miſerable Ones, you Periſh Wonderfully! O Miſerable Ones, you fall into hands, which it is a fearful Thing to fall into!

THERE once came unto an unhappy Man, that Meſſage, Jer. XXVIII. 16. This Year thou ſhalt Dy. Man, Thou knoweſt not thy Time; And therefore the Meſſage may be brought unto thee, This Year thou mayſt Dy. But what if the Dead Warrant could be more evidently ſhown thee, O Thou Priſoner of the Earth: And it could be more poſitively ſaid, This Year thou ſhalt Dy? Wouldeſt thou not Immediately Retire to Conſider thy ways; Immediately plead the Sacrifice of a Glorious CHRIST for the Salvation of thy Soul, the Righteouſneſs of a Glorious CHRIST, for thy Acceptance with GOD; Immediately give up thy ſelf unto the Holy SPIRIT of the Lord, and with a moſt flaming Agony entreat Him to
take Poſſeſſion of thee! Oh! then do this Immediately, O all ye People every one of you! For, O Man, Thou knowest not thy Time. There is not one of us, but for ought he knows, he may Dy before this Week be out: Man, For ought thou knoweſt, This Night thy Soul may be required of thee!

BUT, my Friends, If your Time, when it comes find you unprepared, and alienated from the Life of GOD, what a Lamentable Condition do you fall into! what amazing Lamentations are you thrown into! The doleful Cry, Lord, Lord, Open to us! what will it avail. Twill be All too Late! All too Late! But the Horror of ſuch a Confuſion, O conſider of it before it be too late.

YEA, Conſider me as now coming to you with a Meſſage from the Dead, and a Meſſage directed more peculiarly and pathetically to the YOUNG PEOPLE among us; and a Meſſage which brings with it a Demand of EARLY PIETY, and their Immediate Converſion to GOD, and Eſpouſal to their SAVIOUR.

AN Early Death, and a very Sudden One too, ſhould never occur, without our Apprehending a Voice of the Glorious GOD unto the Survivers in it. Yea, The Voice of the Lord Cries to the City, and very particularly to the YOUNG PEOPLE of the City; The Children of Wiſdom will hearken unto it, and with awakened Souls Lift up their Cries to Heaven upon it; Oh! That before I am cut down, I may bring forth ſome Fruit unto GOD!

THE famous Waldo, whoſe Name has been ſo conſiderable among the Waldenſian Witneſſes of our Lord, was brought home to GOD, and made a Prayerful, Watchful, Fruitful Walker with GOD all the reſt of his Days, upon his beholding a Young Friend of his fall down Suddenly Dead before him. And what? Shall never any more, come to Think on their Ways, and make haſte into a Walk with GOD, upon ſuch an awakening Spectacle!

THO' the Child Samuel, were a very Religious Child, and a bright Exemple of EARLY PIETY, we find, that no leſs than Three times over, the moſt Holy GOD, from the Holy of Holies, call'd unto him, and he was not aware whoſe Voice it was; he was not ſenſible that there was the Voice of GOD in the call. Alas, 'Tis an Error whereto we are all too often liable; and the leſs of EARLY PIETY there is in Young People, the more liable they are unto it. Children, There is a Voice to you, in what you have ſeen; and a Voice as much directed unto you, as if you were like Samuel, by Name called upon: and it is a Voice wherein your EARLY PIETY is very audibly & awfully called for. But are you aware, whoſe Voice it is? 'Tis the Voice of the moſt Glorious GOD, and of a SAVIOUR waiting that He may be Gracious to you. Oh! Liſten to the Voice, Anſwer to the Voice; and ſay, Lord, Speak, for thy Servant hears; and I will be thy Servant: I am Ready to comply with thy whole will in all hearty Obedience! But what, Oh! what is the Voice, to be thus hearkened to! The Voice is, Oh! Immediately go thro' the Proceſs
of Repentance, which the Life of thy Soul depends upon! The Voice is; Oh! Immediately by coming into the Covenant of GOD get thy Soul bound up in the Bundle of Life! The Voice is, 'Oh! Immediately Deny all Ungodlineſs & Worldly Luſts, and come into the Reſolutions of a Godly and a Sober and a Righteous Life! Thou knowest not how ſoon thy Time to do theſe Neceſſary Things may be over with thee.

NO doubt, There are many Young People among us, who have ſome Convictions on their Minds, That things are not with them, as they ſhould be; and they muſt no longer continue as they are : Nor are they without ſome feeble Purpoſes, I will not offend any more. Children, Beware leſt you Sin away theſe Convictions, and a Penal Blindneſs and Hardneſs be what you ſhall thereupon be for ever left unto. We read concerning Sampſon, That while he was yet in his Youth, perhaps a very Young Lad; Judg. XIII. 25. The Spirit of the Lord began to move him at times. Thus, there are many Young People, who feel the Spirit of the Lord beginning to move them at times; and they feel Pious Motions in their Hearts; They think, They will ſhake off their Vain Company; They will take up the Religion of the Cloſet; They will prepare for, and approach to, the Holy Table. But, Oh! Don't loſe theſe Motions; and let not the Spirit of the Lord be provoked by your contempt of His Motions to Depart from you. Wo to them, when I depart from them, ſaith the Lord! It was among the Dying words, which the late Eminent Profeſſor of Theology in the Univerſity of St.
Andrews, in Scotland, uſed unto one of his Children; You ſeem ſome-times to have Convictions; Beware how you treat them. They are the most dangerous things that ever you meddled with.[Mr. Haldburton.] Each of them is a Meſſenger of GOD. If you ſeek not GOD, and if you deſpiſe the Meſſenger of GOD, He will be terribly avenged on you.

IN the Firmament of the Sacred Scriptures, what a Terrible Thunderclap is That! Prov I. 28. They ſhall ſeek me Early, and they ſhall not find me! Our Bleſſed REDEEMER, who is the Wiſdom of GOD, ſays, They that ſeek me Early ſhall find me. How and why is it then ſaid, They ſhall ſeek me Early, and they ſhall not find me! There is a ſad Solution of it. There is the SAVIOUS Early; and there is, the SINNERS Early. The propoſal of the SAVIOUR is, To Day if thou wilt hear my Voice. Yea, Aſſoon as thou dost hear of me, obey me, and ſubmit unto me. Betimes, Quickly, Preſently, without any Delay, make a ſurrender of thy ſelf and thy All unto me. But now, the SINNER puts off his cares to get into the Righteouſneſs of GOD, until all his Youth have been ſpent in the way of his own heart, and Satan his had his Marrow, and he begins to feel Deſtruction coming as a Whirlwind upon him. Then he thinks 'tis Early enough to become a Seeker of GOD. This, This is the EARLY, which Mercy is denied unto. This the Early, which the Abuſed Patience of GOD will not permit the Sinner to find Mercy in! You know the conſequence. Oh! Be perſwaded, knewing the Terror of the Lord.

BUT I leave the work in the hands of another Preacher, and a flaming one. 'Tis a Preacher that will go home with you; and there I intreat you to Hearken unto him, that GOD may hearken unto you another Day. Let Conſcience now do its office. I refer the whole Iſſue to the Conſcience of the Hearer; and I beſeech you, that you would in a due Retirement this very Evening, hear what your Conſciences will ſpeak upon this point; What ſhould be done by One who does not know his Time, nor know whether he ſhall have one Day more, to do what he has to do, that he may be Happy to all ETERNITY.
